item.title: About This Site
item.description: This website is built with two technical tools: the Hugo static website generator and the org-mode exporter for Hugo. The site content is (mostly!) written in the org-mode syntax, using the Emacs text editor. When I need to make changes, I change the source code, export to Hugo, and then sync the changed web pages to a webserver. This sounds complicated but actually it’s extremely easy. The source text and some initial documentation are online at Github.

item.title: Glossary
item.description: This is a list of terms from the readings that seemed particularly enigmatic to me when I first encountered them. Please email me with suggestions if you think we should add more to this list! benthic: related to the lowest layers of a body of water, e.g. the sediments endemic: unique to a particular region (usually of a species, e.g., “the freshwater wetlands of the upper St. Lawrence estuary have many endemic plant species” hyporheic: a region beneath and alongside a stream bed, where there is mixing of shallow groundwater and surface water lacrustine: lake-like portions of a river system lentic: related to still fresh water littoral: the part of a lake or river that is near to the shore lotic: related to fast-moving fresh water oligotrophic: having low levels of nutrients periphyton: freshwater organisms attached to or clinging to plants and other objects projecting above the bottom sediments podzols: sandy, nutrient-poor soils like those found in much of the Ottawa River basin riparian: related to the shores of the river rotifers: small, usually microscopic & often planktonic, animals living in the water vascular plants: plants with xylem and phloem, i.

item.title: Wild Water: History and Culture of Rivers
item.description: Logistics Instructor: Matt Price Email: matt.price@utoronto.ca Office Hrs: SS 3077 T 1:30-2:45 Course Meetings: Wed 3-5, WE 52 About Wild Water This course explores the history and culture of rivers – the “wild waters” which have played (and continue to play!) a pivotal role in so many of the world’s cultures. Like a river itself, the course meanders, rushes, then slows, ebbs and flows.
